creator: @next

content: Assuming you are a novice at Linux, I will speak as a novice myself. Thunderbird is already there, so your first task is locating where the profile is stored (which could vary depending on the distribution). Then, it's just a matter of making a copy of your Windows profile and copying into the same location as the Linux profile was, overlaying the one there.
creator: davidsk

content:
Agreed.

On Debian, on which Mint is ultimately based, the profile is in ~/.thunderbird.

If after copying it the Mint version seems to not be using that profile press Alt-H then Alt-I to get the Troubleshooting Information screen. Look down the blue block at the left for Profiles. Click about:profiles next to it. That brings up a screen where you can choose which profile to use, ie the one you copied rather than the one Thunderbird created on Mint when it was installed.
creator: thepillenwerfer

content:
FWIW I just found this article suggesting I can drag & drop files locally (in Thunderbird) from an older POP account to a newly created IMAP one:-

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/switch-pop-imap-account

But that's likely to take days!! And AFAICT from experimenting here, it only works for received emails. Sent emails didn't seem copyable when I tried it here.

Surely there's a way to just change the Account Type?
creator: john391

content: Sorry, POP and IMAP are different and a separate account would be needed. However, it is possible to upload both received and sent messages, but it can be problematic if you have a lot of messages. A compromise might be to migrate your POP message folders to Local Folders and manage them from there, using the IMAP account going forward.
creator: davidsk

content:
Many thanks david, I'll give some thought to your Local Folders suggestion.

BTW, am I right in thinkng that IMAP saves messages remotely, rather than on my local machine? I'm not quite sure if that'd be a blessing or a curse :-)
creator: john391

content: IMAP keeps all messages on the server. Many link that as it allows interaction with account from multiple locations and from phone.

content:
I'm on 115.12.2 on Debian and it works fine. I take it you you can print from other programs OK?

I've never had cause to print an e-mail from this version of Thunderbird so certainly haven't done any special set-up before just testing it.

I can only suggest the obvious things you'll probably have already done, ie re-boot and remove and re-add the printer.
